messageBody:
I just thought I would point out that (at least according to some) you are
smoking crack!

According to the Sybex book "The Complete Java 2" Second Edition (Robert,
Heller, Ernest, pgs 192-193):

"Just like any other member, a member inner class may be marked static.
When applied to a variable, static means that the variable is associated
with the class, rather than with any particular instance of the class.
When applied to an inner class, the meaning is similar. Specifically, a
static inner class does not have any reference to an enclosing instance."

The example the book gives is:

public class MyOuter {
public static class MyInner {
}
public static void main(String[] args) {
MyInner aMyInner = new MyOuter.MyInner();
}
}

An inner class most definately does NOT need to be bound to an outer class
as is proved by the code snippet above. It is true that a non-static inner
class DOES need to be bound to an enclosing class though.

For less information in a more confused manner see the Java Language
Specification 2nd edition section 8.1.2.

-Phil

I just thought I would point out that (at least according to some)
there is no such thing as a 'static inner class'. An 'inner' class
MUST be bound to an instance of the outer class, and thus can't be
static. What you are talking about here I think is referred to as a
'nested' class. Which is declared exactly like you would expect a
'static inner class' to be declared if that's what it was called:-). I
remember hearing the term 'top level nested class' I think it was in
an article on jRoundup.com.

I know, not exactly relevant to the discussion.. I'll get back to work
:-)

I don't recall anyone mentioning that if for some reason you need
access to a private member to do your test. E.g. to verify internal
state of your object that is not easily verifiable via public or
protected methods, then a inner class would help. I'm new to Unit
Testing so there is probably something else that is wrong with that
:-). It seems that there are occasionally valid reasons to do that
though.

Scott
